unnormalised: Someone asked me if it's imp to use "Mr." or "Ms." these days, especially since everyone's getting all chill and informal. Honestly, it kinda depends, no? Like, if you're emailing your boss, maybe stick to "Mr. Sharma" or "Ms. Khan" just to be safe. Shows respect, you know? Plus, some older folks still appreciate it, like my grandpa always wants to be called "Shri R.K. Gupta".
normalised: Someone asked me if it is important to use "Mister" or "Miss" these days, especially since everyone is getting all chill and informal. Honestly, it kind of depends, no? Like, if you are emailing your boss, maybe stick to "Mister Sharma" or "Miss Khan" just to be safe. Shows respect, you know? Plus, some older folks still appreciate it, like my grandpa always wants to be called "Shri R-K Gupta".

unnormalised: But yeah, with friends or younger colleagues, it's totally cool to just use their name. No need for "Mr." or "Ms." at all. Unless you're being sarcastic, then "Mr. Know-it-all" might be funny, haha. It's all about reading the room, I guess. And nowadays, lots of people just use their first name in emails too.

unnormalised: Also, keep in mind the context. Like, if you're writing a formal letter for a government job application, definitely use "Mr./Ms." But on social media, come on, nobody uses that stuff. And what about Dr. Iyer? You def use that title! The whole "Mx." thing is also getting more common for non-binary folks, so it's good to be aware of that too.

unnormalised: So bottom line: use your judgment. Err on the side of formality when in doubt, especially with authority figures or older generations. But don't stress too much about it in casual settings. Just be respectful and observant, and you'll be fine!
